thread.title: Late Andrew Copp goal gives Detroit Red Wings victory amid plane, weather issues
thread.title_full: Late Andrew Copp goal gives Detroit Red Wings victory amid plane, weather issues

author: @type
title: Late Andrew Copp goal gives Detroit Red Wings victory amid plane, weather issues
text:
Toronto â€” Not sure why anyone would want to skip the Red Wings game Sunday, but anyone who did missed an entertaining game. Andrew Copp scored at 18 minutes, 20 seconds of the third period, giving the Wings a dramatic 4-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs. Copp's eighth goal was a shot from the hashmarks, as Copp got the puck and found some open ice, then fired a shot past goaltender Ilya Samsonov.
Lucas Raymond scored into an empty net to clinch the victory.
The Wings (22-16-5) have earned points in six consecutive games (5-0-1) and are now one point behind Toronto for third place in the Atlantic Division (50-49). The Wings now occupy the No. 1 wild-card spot in the Eastern Conference.
"It feels amazing," Wings captain Dylan Larkin said of the victory.
There's a reason this one felt so special.
While the Detroit sports world was excited to get to a television set to watch the Lions, the Wings were simply glad to get to Toronto.
BOX SCORE: Red Wings 4, Maple Leafs 2
The Wings encountered weather and mechanical issues after Saturday's game and never left Detroit. They returned home in the middle of the night, and came back Sunday, only to wait for an available plane to arrive.
The Wings didn't reach Scotiabank Arena until 6:15 p.m., coach Derek Lalonde said, for what was scheduled to be a 7 p.m. start, was pushed back to 7:30 p.m., then finally 7:52 p.m.
"Real good win, a real unique 24 hours," Lalonde said. "I haven't experienced 24 hours like that, I don't think anyone in the league has. Weather, mechanical issues, it was crazy. But our guys handled it pretty well. There were things we couldn't control in the last 24 hours but the one thing was effort and execution and the guys did a pretty job there."
Larkin compared it to a preseason game, when the Wings would have arrived late in the afternoon for a game that night.
"Fly in and get here a little bit late but our staff, from top to bottom, all of them did above and beyond to have everything we needed to play," Larkin said. "We had every reason to not show up and we showed up. We've talked about our locker room and how close it is, and that (the victory) should show what it says about the guys in this room."
Originally scheduled to fly to Fort Lauderdale for the rest of this road trip after game, the Wings are now flying Monday after staying the night in Toronto.
The only negative in the game for the Wings was losing forward Patrick Kane in the first period.
Kane was involved in a pair of collisions and suffered a lower-body injury that knocked him out of the game. There was no immediate update, but the concern likely is the right hip on which Kane had resurfacing surgery in June.
Lalonde had no further update on Kane, after the game.
"(But) I don't think it's related to his hip," Lalonde said. "But again, I don't have all the information on it yet."
Daniel Sprong (his 11th goal) and Larkin (17th goal) had Wings goals, while goaltender James Reimer made 28 saves in his first start since Dec. 27. Sprong tied the score 2-2 at 2:46 of the third period.
Sprong took advantage of Toronto defenseman Morgan Rielly's stick exploding at the blue line and drove in alone, using a nifty move to his backhand to beat Samsonov.
Reimer was impressive, especially as the game progressed, while solidifying the victory.
"He was unbelievable," Larkin said. "You look at our recent success, it's been goaltending. He was called upon tonight and he gave us 60 minutes, made big save after big save. It's hard when you're not playing a lot but he came in and did his job well. We're real happy for him."
Reimer was happy to cap the unusual day by contributing to the win.
"A ton of adversity, backs against the wall, schedule is all messed up, flight is late, and all that and those are the game you can cave or you can dig in," Reimer said. "As a group, to a man, we dug in. So much adversity, but if we don't have the character we have in here, you kind of give up and lick our wounds and try again next game.
"But we dug in, and to a man, I'm proud of the guys."
Pontus Holmberg and Mitch Marner scored the Leafs' goals.
